newsitem.title: SLOVAKIA: Slovak trade gap widens in September.
newsitem.headline: Slovak trade gap widens in September.

text.p: Slovakia's 1996 foreign trade deficit widened again in September, but at a slower rate than in August, the Slovak Statistical Bureau (SUSR) said on Tuesday.

The deficit of 2.092 billion crowns ($67.55 million) in September narrowed from a 3.930 billion crown deficit in August, but imports mostly of cars, chemicals, metal products and aeroplanes swelled the cumulative 1996 shortfall.

The SUSR said the deficit for the first nine months widened to 37.17 billion crowns in current prices, from 35.078 billion for the January-August period. This compares with a trade surplus of 405 million crowns for the first nine months of 1995.
In a report, the SUSR said imports grew 24.9 percent in Septmeber versus the same month a year ago to 234 billion crowns, while exports were up by 4.9 percent to 197 billion.
The SUSR said about 39 billion crowns of imports comprised fossil fuels and mineral oils.
Imports for construction of the Mochovce nuclear power plant took up 35.9 billion crowns, while car imports totalled 21.1 billion crowns.
Metal and steel products imports totalled 7.521 billion crowns, while the imports of the airplanes took up 5.814 billion crowns.
"The import volume was mainly influenced by higher imports of motor vehicles, aeroplanes and ships ... compared with the same period of last year," the SUSR said.
"In decline were imports of animal and vegetable fats and oils," it said.
Car imports rose by 8.999 billion crowns during January- September, while imports of airplanes increased by 5.201 billion crowns, both compared with the same period of the last year, the SUSR said.
The single-month commodities import figures for September and August were not available.
The main export commodities were iron and rolled steel, accounting for 27.6 billion crowns in the nine month period.
The Czech Republic remained Slovakia's leading trading partner, accounting for 31.5 percent of total exports and 25.6 percent of imports.
Germany and Austria were next with a 20.8 and 6.1 percent share of total Slovak exports.
The second and third largest share of Slovakia's imports came from Russia and Germany, accounting for 18 and 14.5 percent respectively.
Trade with OECD countries produced a 10.535 billion crown deficit, while that with Russia was 35.421 billion in deficit.
Meanwhile, Slovakia had a surplus of 10.209 billion crowns with the Central European Free Trade Agreement (CEFTA) countries.
-- Peter Javurek, Bratislava Newsroom, 42-7-563-3687 ($1=30.97 Slovak Crown)
